87293.title: ornamentally arranged Native American projectile points
87293.creation_notes: "Earliest" date = 3000 BC because that is the earliest artifact from the Native Arts of the Americas collection known to have been made in the (now) US;"Latest" date = accession year. These fields are filled out somewhat arbitrarily for search purposes only; the Earliest/Latest dates were not provided by Mellon Curator Dr. Christian Feest and should not be used or provided outside the IMA.
87293.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. Townsend, Jr.
87293.provenance:
Earl C. Townsend, Jr. [1914-2007] and Emily Townsend [1920-1988] {1}, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the John Herron Art Institute, now the Indianapolis Museum of Art, in 1964.

{1} also known as Elizabeth Emily MacNab Townsend

18613.title: wedding dress
18613.description: Wedding dress made of off-white silk satin lavishly trimmed with silk chiffon, silk net, lace and artificial pearls.  The dress is "princess" line with continuous fabric from shoulder to the hem.  The dress shaped at the waist and hips with vertical rows of inserted neckline and collar of silk net.  The bodice is lavishly trimmed with layers of silk satin decorated with pearls, lace and decorated net. The sleeves are short and puffed and are made from multiple layers of decorative fabrics.  The silk satin in the skirt is split into separate panels at the front.   The center front of the skirt has an inserted panel of silk net with rows of horizontal pleats across the bottom.  (The underskirt is visible through the net.)   There are also two inserted panels of silk net on each side of the dress.  The edges of the inserted panels are trimmed with lace.  There are droppers of artificial pearls scattered throughout the silk net.
18613.credit_line: Gift of Carolyn Garrigues Scofield in memory of her grandmother Caroline Burford Danner
18613.medium_support: silk satin, silk chiffon, linen lace, silk taffeta, cotton organza, artificial pearls and glass beads
18613.provenance: Caroline Buford Danner (Indianapolis); Carolyn Garrigues Scofield (granddaughter of Caroline Danner), Providence, Rhode Island; IMA December 19, 1986.
18613.dimensions: L: 43 in. (waist to hem) | L: 15 in. (shoulder to waist)

extended_text.content:
Caroline Ella Burford and Henry Rose Danner were married on May 16, 1906, in the Burford mansion, located at 1330 N. Meridian Street in Indianapolis.

A detailed description of the dress was printed in the Indianapolis News:

"The bride wore an exquisite gown of white satin . . . . The satin was trimmed with purling of tulle, dotted with seed pearls . . . , and the long veil was caught with a diamond crown, holding a coronet of orange blossoms. The bridal bouquet was an arm cluster of valley lilies, tied with streamers of tulle, knotted with orange blossoms."
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

18613.exhibit_history:
I Do: The Marriage of Art and Fashion
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery
June 11, 2006 - April 22, 2007.

The bodice is lavishly trimmed with layers of silk satin decorated with pearls, lace and decorated net. The sleeves are short and puffed and are made from multiple layers of decorative fabrics.  The silk satin in the skirt is split into separate panels at the front.   The center front of the skirt has an inserted panel of silk net with rows of horizontal pleats across the bottom.  (The underskirt is visible through the net.)   There are also two inserted panels of silk net on each side of the dress.  The edges of the inserted panels are trimmed with lace. 36303.title: evening dress
36303.description: print designed by Halston, spiral/Stally bias cut, strapless tied in the front
36303.provenance: Elizabeth Weymouth (b. 1943), New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1985).

extended_text.content:
Halston was a master of creating dresses that were sexy and elegant by exposing just the right amount of skin.

The print on this strapless dress was designed by Halston, and the style reveals his adherence to Minimalist principles in his designs. The fabric is cut on the bias in a spiral shape. The uncluttered construction results in a classic silhouette.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

36303.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

57699.title: Ade Vodun
57699.description: red conical hat with various colorful beads
57699.credit_line: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crane Fund
57699.provenance: Sonya Clark, Madison; purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art (2002).

extended_text.content: Sonya Clark is an African-American artist who is inspired by African cultures.  In this work, she focuses on the cone-like pointed forms of Yoruba king's crowns.  A similar form also communicates power in the neighboring Benin Kingdom, where the mother of a king wears a pointed headpiece adorned with red coral beads.  The surface ornaments relate to sequin-covered objects of Haitian religious traditions.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

57699.exhibit_history:
African Inspirations; Sculpted Headwear by Soyna Clark
University of Iowa Museum of Art (organizer) 2001
Indianapolis Museum of Art 2001

13928.title: Gazelle bowl
13928.creation_notes: Earliest/Latest dates refer to possible manufacturing date, which could be as late as 1939, the year the bowl was acquired.
13928.description: According to original catalog card: Fine example of three processes;- the semi-globular bowl is blown; the base on whcih it rests is cut, and the band of gazelles upon teh bowl is made by the copper wheel method (engraved).
13928.dimensions:
7 x 7 x 7 in. (installed)
A) bowl: 6 x 7 x 7 in.
B) stand: 1-3/4 x 6-1/8 x 6-1/8 in.

extended_text.content:
This engraved bowl is a good example of glass in the Art Deco style: opulent, with geometric patterns and animal motifs.

The streamlined shapes of Swedish Art Deco heavily influenced the new look of Steuben glass in the 1930s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12958.title: evening dress
12958.creation_notes: year as written on incoming TR- 1962
12958.description: two-piece lamp-shade style ensemble; black chantilly lace, silk crepe, trimmed with fox fur
12958.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Samuel C. Goldberg
12958.medium_support: Chantilly lace, silk crepe, fox fur
12958.provenance: purchased at The William H. Block Company department store, Indianapolis (early 1940s); Mrs. Samuel C. Goldberg, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1980).

extended_text.content: Norell’s understanding of design and his technical expertise made his ready-to-wear garments as fine as any made-to-order outfits. This rare and unusual dress embodies everything Norell represented. The lampshade-shaped Chantilly lace top is edged with fox fur. A simple, straightcut, floor-length skirt completes the outfit. This silhouette was made popular by the French couturier Paul Poiret around 1910 and was reintroduced in the 1930s by other French designers.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12958.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy: Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013

37163.title: evening dress
37163.medium_support: silk organza, bugle beads, glass beads, sequins
37163.provenance: Halston Enterprises, Incoporated, New York; given to IMA July 9, 1982.

extended_text.content:
When Halston began using glitter in his designs, the results were sexier and more spectacular than any other designer's. He said, "I can do the jazziest clothes, dress the jazziest people."

This chemise dress with a dipping hemline is embroidered in an all-over design. The fabric has been dyed to create a range of hues, from deep yellow to orange.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

37163.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009
